SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Heartburn is frequently reported by patients with achalasia before treatment
However, the esophageal sensitivity to acid as a possible mediator of this symptom has not been previously evaluated
AIM: To evaluate the prevalence of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms and the esophageal sensitivity to acid perfusion in patients with untreated achalasia
METHODS: Forty patients with achalasia were prospectively evaluated
Forty-three patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease comprised the control group (ten of them with Barrett's esophagus)
Symptoms were evaluated by a structured clinical questionnaire
Objective assessment was performed by ambulatory 24-h esophageal pH monitoring and endoscopy
Esophageal sensitivity to acid was evaluated by esophageal perfusion of ClH 0.1 N
RESULTS: Fifteen (37%) of the 40 patients with achalasia presented heartburn, but only four of them had esophagitis and/or abnormal esophageal pH recording
Eight patients had abnormal pH recording
The esophagus was sensitive to acid in seven (17%) patients with achalasia, three of them with heartburn and one with abnormal pH recording
In the control group, 40 of 43 (93%) presented heartburn
Sensitivity to acid was lower in patients with achalasia than in those with gastroesophageal reflux disease with or without Barrett's esophagus
CONCLUSIONS: The prevalence of heartburn in patients with achalasia is high, although its association with objective indicators of gastroesophageal reflux disease is weak
Patients with achalasia have lower esophageal sensitivity to acid than patients with GERD, suggesting that heartburn is does not arise from this condition
